body: I'm evaluating ways to allow pip users to benefit from the change as well without static-linking.
Also removed the deprecated code example.

With alpha=1, this change is fully compatible with previously trained model.

The symbol loaded by mx.model.load_checkpoint is slightly different with the one return by mobilenet.get_symbol. The global_pool kernel size is calculated depending on resolution in this change.

Test by adding following codes into sparse embedding forward,

```
mshadow::Stream<cpu>* s = ctx.get_stream<cpu>();
mshadow::Tensor<cpu, 1, char> w1 = ctx.requested[0]
         .get_space_typed<cpu, 1, char>(mshadow::Shape1(10), s);
mshadow::Tensor<cpu, 1, char> w2 = ctx.requested[1]
         .get_space_typed<cpu, 1, char>(mshadow::Shape1(10), s);
LOG(INFO) << " equal " << (w1.dptr_ == w2.dptr_);
```
Then run test of sparse embedding.
Output,
```
/home/ubuntu/fix_rsc_mx/python/mxnet/ndarray/sparse.py:664: RuntimeWarning: Assigning non-NDArray object to RowSparseNDArray is not efficient
  RuntimeWarning)
[13:41:19] src/operator/tensor/./indexing_op.h:415:  equal 0
[13:41:19] src/operator/tensor/./indexing_op.h:415:  equal 0
[13:41:19] src/operator/tensor/./indexing_op.h:415:  equal 0
```
Anything to address?
We only allow one temp space per operator

Regarding your question about CPU performance - it will mostly not be affected by bulk execution, since the executor doesn't explicit sync stream anyway (implicitly done by openmp)

@dwSun Names are inconsistent.
The original param names are 
```
'conv12_pointwise_bias', 'batchnorm1_gamma', 'conv12_pointwise_weight', 'conv7_depthwise_bias'
```
Now they are
```
'conv_9_dw_conv2d_weight', 'conv_1_batchnorm_beta', 'conv_8_dw_conv2d_weight'
```
Which means old models are no longer usable after this change. Can you follow the old names to not break the backward compatibility?
Other changes looks good.
Got it. Thanks.

I followed the install instruction in mxnet website, and I add #include "kvstore/kvstore_local.h" in file batch_norm_v1-inl.h. After that, I compiled the makefile using "make -j $(nproc) USE_OPENCV=1 USE_BLAS=openblas USE_CUDA=1 USE_CUDA_PATH=/usr/local/cuda USE_CUDNN=1", then I got the warning.

@piiswrong @reminisce Thanks for your replies!

1. As for the shared states,
    1. Can multiple `FMutateInputs` be used? Or should I just return multiple variables for one `FMutateInputs`? Can you provide an example?
    2. How can the registered `FMutateInputs` be used? Currently I haven't found the position in batch normalization implementation files where the [`std::vector<uint32_t>{3, 4}`](https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/pull/8302/files?diff=split#diff-c7e5df696274a535051595cc84f35353R445) is used.
    3. What if the size of the variable storing intermediate results can only be determined during the computation on the fly? In such cases, I will need to compute the size of the variable and allocate the space dynamically (`Blob::Reshape()` in Caffe). And I will need to switch between CPU and GPU storage during the computation (`Blob::cpu_data()` and `Blob::gpu_data()` in Caffe), since the values stored at GPU can not be directly used in host code.
    4. BTW, why the [`inputs()`](https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/pull/8302/files#diff-6e6adac74a85b946a9a8ac6e5875e20aR232) in the `BatchNormGradCompute()` have the length of 11 and the [`in_data_start`](https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/pull/8302/files#diff-6e6adac74a85b946a9a8ac6e5875e20aR235) equals 3?
2. As for operator with learnable parameters,
    1. I have checked out the convolution implementation files. The only thing I find is that the `weight` and `bias` are treated similarly to the `data` as one of the operator inputs. But what exactly is it that distinguishes between input data and operator parameters (so that the program knows the parameters need to be stored and updated)?
    2. In the convolution implementation, `FResourceRequest` is used to claim one extra resource needed. If I need multiple resources, what should I do? Should I just return a longer resource request vector and define more values in the `ConvolutionOpResource` enum as below?
```
enum ConvolutionOpResource { kTempSpace1, kTempSpace2, kTempSpace2 };
...
.set_attr<FResourceRequest>("FResourceRequest", [](const NodeAttrs& n) {
  return std::vector<ResourceRequest>{ ResourceRequest::kTempSpace, ResourceRequest::kTempSpace, ResourceRequest::kTempSpace };
})
```
3. As for the macros, I can checkout their definitions on my own. But I hope there are some clear explanations and examples telling me when I should use them. This allows users to start to develop their own code more quickly. In Caffe, I know I only need to use one `CUDA_KERNEL_LOOP` macro in most cases. But in MXNet, I feel totally blank, not knowing whether I should look for and use macros. It would be low efficient if each developer needs to examine all the macro definitions on their own.
    - The [beginner guide](https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/blob/master/docs/how_to/add_op_in_backend.md) shows usages of `MSHADOW_TYPE_SWITCH`, `MXNET_ASSIGN_REQ_SWITCH` and `KERNEL_ASSIGN`. The former two can be easily understood, while the last one seems to only suit simple computations. In more complex computations, one will have pre-processings (e.g. computing sizes of intermediate variables and allocate memory dynamically), multiple callings of different CUDA kernel functions, post-processings, etc.
4. Can my own code be put in completely separate locations? For example, the MXNet codebase lies at `<root>/<sub_root_1>/mxnet`, and I want to put my own code at `<root>/<sub_root_2>/<my_own_code_dir>`.
5. Hi, @cjolivier01, could you help me with this?
Were you able to find the cause of the issue?

I don't quite understand your need, but it doesn't look like the behavior you want by using `take`. The functionality of this op is explained in the documentation.
https://mxnet.incubator.apache.org/api/python/ndarray/ndarray.html?highlight=take#mxnet.ndarray.take

If it is not what you need, post your question here so that people can help from there.
https://discuss.mxnet.io/

Where are these tutorials today? The links are all broken and I cannot find any simple regression/classification examples. Why does every lstm have to be character based... have checked github, crossvalidated, stackexchange...

1.
i-ii You can take a look at this line: https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/pull/8302/files#diff-8417803f764246e7864dc1d54c256dcfR661. It tells the indices of aux data in the input data vector as registered in the form of `vector<uint32_t>{3, 4}`.
iii MXNet only supports dynamically allocating memory space for sparse tensors in the format of row-sparse and csr.
iv I guess inputs[1] and inputs[2] stores the grads of `mean` and `var`. Does it explain why there are 11 inputs to you?
2. 
i weights as a param in convolution just specifies the shape of filter. The graph executor will allocate a tensor for it. Once you define the backward function for a input tensor, it becomes learnable.
ii Right now, MXNet only supports allocating temp space once per forward/backward function. You can pre-calculate the total space you need and allocate once for all.
3. Agree that too many macros lower the readability of the code and makes running gdb tracing harder. But the ones you listed are mostly the common ones you are going to see while writing cpp code and they let you escape from writing quite a lot of boilerplate code.
4. I guess so. You just need to write a correct Makefile to include headers and link the MXNet lib.

Yes. Is your use case like

user | item 
---- | --- 
1:1, 100:1 | 3:1, 300:1 

For now, user need create a single `libsvm` format file.
I'd suggest we test test_ctc_loss_train in a loop on a CPU instance and see if it fails after running for an extended period.

I mean

|  label        | user history clicked items | item  |  user history click rate |
| ---------  | -------------                      |-------------|-----|
| 1                | 1:293 1:394  1:743            | 2:482 | 3:0.05 |
| 0               | 1:128 1:91                           | 2:232 | 3:0.14 |

`csv` format don't suit for this data. But if `libsvm` format like you said `293:1.0 394:1.0 743:1.0 482:1.0`, it don't separate two field `user history clicked items` and `item` because we don't want inner cross in the same one field.

@leezu Just to clarify, you're attempting to pip install and then run mxnet right?  You're not compiling or linking against the package?  

Would you be able to let us know what distribution you're using?  You can install the required package on ubuntu with 'sudo apt-get install libgfortran3'.

@zhreshold, I checked the symbol, with:
```py
import mobilenet_mine  # my PR version
import mobilenet_origin  # 41394a448a92efbe7704fe21c48a8504fd8d3edc,example/image-classification/symbols/mobilenet.py

sym_orig = mobilenet_origin.get_symbol(10)
sym_mine = mobilenet_mine.get_symbol(10)
sym_mine_compcat = mobilenet_mine.get_symbol_compact(10)

with open('sym_orig.json', mode='w') as of:
    of.write(sym_orig.tojson())

with open('sym_mine.json', mode='w') as of:
    of.write(sym_mine.tojson())

with open('sym_mine_compcat.json', mode='w') as of:
    of.write(sym_mine_compcat.tojson())
```
Those json files are identical to each other.

I had reimplemented nasnet_large [https://github.com/qingzhouzhen/incubator-mxnet/blob/nasnet/python/mxnet/gluon/model_zoo/vision/nasnet.py](https://github.com/qingzhouzhen/incubator-mxnet/blob/nasnet/python/mxnet/gluon/model_zoo/vision/nasnet.py) which refers to [Torch implement](https://github.com/Cadene/pretrained-models.pytorch/blob/master/pretrainedmodels/models/nasnet.py) and [Tensorflow implement](https://github.com/tensorflow/models/tree/master/research/slim/nets/nasnet), but I have no so many GPUs to train the model, any one could work on whis would be great.
Is it a problem with the mxnet build version? I'm getting same error and do not have reShape or Shape anywhere in my code.

@KellenSunderland Yes, I'm referring to the case where a user on a distribution with gcc version >= 7.2 installs mxnet from pip. Self-compiling is no problem in that case, as mxnet will be linked against the "correct" libgfortran.so.4.

I'm running Gentoo, but Fedora >= 26 should be affected by this as well. Ubuntu seems indeed to package the old libgfortran.so.3 as well (in addition to libgfortran.so.4) but it seems not to be part of the Fedora archives.

@leezu Ok great, thanks for the info, I see what you mean.  I've seen libgfortran.so.3 offered as a compat package on some distribution (iirc Amazon Linux) and I was hoping I could suggest that as a fix.  However the only compat version on Fedora 27 seems to be compat-libgfortran-41 which gets you libgfortran.so.1 and libgfortran.so.4 (neither of which work for mxnet).  Looks like the ABI changed, so I can't think of any way to link to both in the same package off the top of my head.
I can also reproduce this error by `make -j  USE_BLAS=openblas USE_CUDA=1 USE_CUDA_PATH=/usr/local/cuda`

Open question: Since Gluon LeakyReLU is implemented with 
 return F.LeakyReLU(x, act_type='leaky', slope=self._alpha, name='fwd')
and since there is a act_type='prelu' in F.LeakyReLU, why not also implement Gluon PReLU with 
 return F.LeakyReLU(x, act_type='prelu', ...etc
What would be more efficient?

TF has None which means zero https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/5888

pytorch has zeros for round
```python
In [1]: import torch

In [2]: from torch.autograd import Variable

In [3]: x = Variable(torch.randn(4), requires_grad=True)

In [4]: y = x.round()

In [5]: z = y.sum()

In [6]: z.backward()

In [7]: x.grad
Out[7]:
Variable containing:
 0
 0
 0
 0
[torch.FloatTensor of size 4]
```

prepare_mkl.sh is intended for pulling in the mkl small library, which is a dependency of mkl2017. It's not the same thing as the mkl full release which mxnet can use as blas.
prepare_mkl.sh is currently triggered in makefile when USE_MKL2017 is 1. https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/blob/master/MKL_README.md#buildinstall-mxnet-with-mkl

I see. Okay

Difficult to diagnose without access to your platform, looks like the template is inside an "extern C" block. Check the include from the error message to see what's going on.

Try to copy the line that produces the error and add "-E" then open the output file to see what the preprocessed code looks like, then you can check if the template is surrounded by extern C, and confirm that the problem is in your STL version. Alternatively you can use a different STL version.
You can do `make test`, then run the generated binary with `./build/tests/cpp/mxnet_unit_tests` .
@rahul003 Here is the fix. Thank you for notifying me of the bug and apologies for breaking `make test`.
I asked piiswrong about this and apparently the cpp tests aren't run on CI which is in part why PR #7781 didn't catch the bug. (Also in part that I didn't run `make test` before pushing...)
